442.03.text:

the sugar combines with all

485.88.text:

And that's what

So it's really challenging

497.46.text:

vegan treat anywhere else,

1123.05.text:
So I don't know
if it's a secret--

1124.47.text:
JOANNE CHANG: I didn't pay
her to say that, I swear.

1127.06.text:
AUDIENCE: I don't
know if it's a secret,

1128.73.text:
but I've always
wondered what you

1130.60.text:
do with your vegan treats
to make them taste just as

1133.68.text: good as some of the other ones?

1136.77.text:
The vegan muffin recipe is in
the second book, "Flour, too."

1144.29.text:
I don't know what
other people are doing,

1146.00.text:
but we just
substitute the things

1147.94.text:
that-- I mean, if you're
vegan, then you already know.

1150.19.text:
Like instead of milk, we use
soy milk or coconut milk.

1155.01.text: Instead of butter, we use oil.

1158.38.text:
We didn't do anything
for the instead of eggs.

1160.87.text:
I think we just kind
of fiddled around

1163.26.text:
with the oil and the milk to
make it still liquid enough.

1167.37.text:
But I don't know that we
did anything that magical.

1177.35.text:
When we do come up
with a new recipe,

1179.08.text:
we spend a lot of
time experimenting.

1181.44.text:
Everything is weighed
at the bakery.

1183.41.text:
Everything is
weighed to the gram,

1184.83.text:
and we will literally change
things by 1% to 2% iteration

1188.45.text:
after iteration to get to
where we want it to be.

1190.59.text:
In fact, there's an
email thread going

1192.17.text:
on right now about
something that they're like,

1194.58.text:
And I was like, nope,
let's start with 3%.

1196.33.text:
Let's try it first just 3%, and
then we'll see what happens.

1199.86.text: So there's a lot of testing.

1201.33.text:
So the recipe for
the vegan muffin

1203.66.text:
that you're talking about
went through many rounds

1206.92.text:
of maybe it started
out dry at one point,

1208.92.text:
and then we just added
more and more stuff.

1213.97.text: Thanks so much for coming today.

1215.82.text:
Curious if you can talk a
little bit about your process

1218.11.text:
for testing recipes
for a cookbook,

1220.56.text:
and if there's like an average
number of times you test,

1223.85.text:
if you throw it to other
people to test to make sure

1226.87.text:
it's accessible for
the novice baker.

1230.21.text:
So if it's a recipe
that we already

1232.36.text:
have, like the
vegan muffin recipe,

1234.68.text:
which exists at the bakery,
basically what happens

1238.08.text:
is-- so everything's
in metric, and I just

1240.54.text:
reduce it to what seems like
a normal home size amount.

1243.98.text: And then I'll test it myself.

1246.73.text: And I'll go through it once.

1248.16.text:
But just because I
can do it, I know

1249.66.text:
that that doesn't mean that it's
ready for the book, because I

1252.24.text:
know what I'm
thinking, so I need

1253.76.text: to give it to somebody else.

1254.93.text:
So then a baker will test
it within the bakery,

1257.13.text:
just to make sure that it's
kind of the right thing.

1259.52.text:
But even that doesn't
really work from a testing

1262.14.text:
perspective, because
all the bakers know me,

1264.33.text:
and they know what I mean
when I say, do this, do that.

1266.80.text: So then we send it out.

1270.37.text:
Cambridge Culinary will
test recipes for us

1274.77.text:
And so depending on
whatever semester,

1278.46.text:
I'll reach out to the
director and she'll put me

1282.39.text:
And they are on my
email list, and I say,

1284.13.text:
here's a bunch of
recipes I need tested.

1287.28.text:
And then I have a couple
testers who are just people

1289.45.text:
that I've worked closely
with who just test for me.

1293.79.text:
If it's something that
already exists at the bakery,

1296.16.text:
it doesn't take that
many iterations,

1298.93.text:
It's just a matter
of figuring out--

1300.43.text:
like sometimes as you
reduce, reduce, reduce,

1303.11.text: it reduces to a weird number.

1304.65.text:
It reduces to like 1 cup plus
2 tablespoons and 1 teaspoon.

1309.03.text:
And that's not
really that usable,

1311.81.text:
so I'll have to change
things around and change

1314.07.text:
the proportions around just to
make sure that somebody at home

1318.81.text:
But that usually takes
like one, maybe two tries.

1323.62.text:
But if it's a brand-new recipe,
like with the low sugar book,

1327.50.text:
I feel like those
recipes, a good recipe

1330.44.text:
would take four
iterations by me.

1334.51.text:
So that's me trying it out
and then adjusting, adjusting,

1336.93.text:
adjusting, and then by the
fourth time being like,

1339.66.text:
Then I would give it to a baker
and then they would do it.

1342.08.text:
And usually, again, it
was almost the same thing

1345.95.text:
They know me well enough
that they would just make it.

1348.20.text: So that's like a fifth test.

1349.43.text:
And then when we would
send it out to the testers.

1352.41.text:
And usually from there,
I would say about 80%

1355.23.text:
of the time it worked and 20%
of the time I'd get feedback

1360.08.text:
But by then, it was
usually just one iteration,

1362.70.text:
because I would get specific
feedback and I would say,

1365.20.text:
ah, I knew that that
was going to happen.

1369.11.text:
A bad recipe-- or
not a bad recipe.

1372.84.text:
A more challenging
recipe, probably more

1377.51.text:
Again, because we're doing
things in such small--

1380.77.text:
in pastry, there are so many
things that you can vary,

1383.65.text:
If you have 10 ingredients in
your thing, in your recipe,

1386.74.text:
and you're trying to make
it more moist or less

1390.53.text:
sweet or whatever, if you
just adjust one thing,

1393.32.text:
it's going to affect
everything else.

1394.86.text:
So what you want to do
is adjust everything,

1397.31.text:
but then you don't know which
one of those adjustments worked

1400.60.text:
So you have to kind of go
slowly and say, well, I'm

1402.61.text:
just going to reduce the eggs
from four eggs to three eggs

1406.54.text:
Then you have to wait till
it bakes, wait till it cools,

1408.90.text: try it, and then do it again.

1411.15.text:
So it takes a lot of patience,
but it's a lot of fun.

1414.40.text:
And there's a lot of
mistakes along the way

1416.19.text:
that most people don't
view as mistakes.

1419.06.text:
So people like to
eat the mistakes.

1420.92.text:
FEMALE SPEAKER: If you need to
testers for your next cookbook,

1424.24.text:
I'd be happy to send
recipes out to the office.

1427.20.text:
Our office is very
good with feedback.

1429.14.text:
JOANNE CHANG: If you guys
want to test recipes, sure.

1433.55.text:
AUDIENCE: I wondered
about convection oven

1437.26.text:
versus conventional,
and which is your go-to

1439.93.text:
and in what cases will you opt
for the other choice, and why?

1443.79.text:
JOANNE CHANG: We use mostly
convection at this point,

1457.03.text:
and tarts, tart shells,
we'll use convection.

1460.50.text:
And we'll use deck ovens,
or the still ovens,

1463.78.text: for things like bread and cakes.

1465.83.text:
And the difference--
with the convection,

1468.95.text:
you've got the fan
whirring around,

1470.91.text:
which is making the
temperature more consistent,

1473.67.text:
but it is introducing the
element of movement and air.

1477.46.text:
And so for a cookie or a
brioche or something that's

1481.35.text:
relatively stable, I
don't mind that there's

1484.16.text:
air blowing around, because
I just want it to bake,

1486.28.text:
and I want it to bake
relatively evenly.

1487.86.text:
I don't want half
of the brioche to be

1489.44.text: under and half to be over.

1491.85.text:
But a cake-- if you put a cake
in a convection oven, what

1495.42.text:
tends to happen is that the cake
starts to cook on the outside,

1499.18.text:
because you've got
this whirring fan.

1500.91.text:
And then the inside is
still needing time to cook.

1504.01.text:
And so the cake will
sometimes come out

1508.50.text:
It'll finish baking on the
outside first, and by the time

1511.89.text:
the inside is baked it'll be
over-baked on the outside.

1515.04.text:
So we have found
that the still ovens

1517.03.text:
are better for baking cakes,
because it's slow, steady heat.

1522.23.text:
There's no air that's trying
to basically form a crust.

1525.25.text: And that's the same with bread.

1526.54.text:
If you put bread in
the convection oven,

1528.50.text:
the air will cause the skin
of the bread to crust, which

1533.43.text:
means that as the yeast
is trying to expand

1536.34.text:
and as the bread's trying
to get big and airy,

1538.77.text:
it can't because it's
been crusted over.

1540.91.text:
So we prefer doing
that in a still oven.

1544.23.text:
And then even better is if you
can inject some steam in it--

1546.73.text:
take a little water bottle and
put some steam-- it creates

1549.15.text:
a really humid
environment for the bread,

1551.02.text:
so then the bread dough stays
supple as the yeast is growing.

1555.60.text:
And then it doesn't crust over
until the yeast are all dead,

1558.75.text:
and then you get
that crust that's

1568.30.text:
So I had a question
about how you

1571.76.text:
Do you have a
collection of recipes

1573.22.text:
that you're never going to share
that are like the secret ones?

1577.53.text:
The first book was
all the recipes

1579.08.text: that we had at the time.

1580.31.text:
And then since then,
we've done new things.

1582.29.text:
And people will say, how come
you didn't share this recipe?

1584.75.text:
And I'll say, because we
hadn't made it at that point.

1587.14.text:
And the same with
the second book.

1589.08.text:
I put a bunch of salads
in the second book,

1590.87.text:
and then we came up with a
new salad menu at the bakery,

1593.12.text:
and everyone's like, where's
the Green Goddess dressing?

1595.11.text:
And I said, oh, we
hadn't made it by then.

1597.19.text:
So the issue for us now is if
somebody wants a recipe that

1601.76.text:
I can give you the recipe to
make like 10 gallons of Green

1604.66.text:
Goddess, and if you want
to do the math-- or I

1607.61.text:
can do the math as well and
just give it to you in grams.

1610.14.text:
But I don't have home-friendly
recipes for everything,

1615.28.text:
so that's usually
the limiting factor.

1617.43.text:
If somebody says,
I love this recipe.

1619.01.text:
I'll just say to them, I can
give it to you in the big batch

1622.65.text:
and I can do the math, just
divided it by 50 or whatever.

1626.17.text:
But depending on
your comfort level,

1628.85.text:
you can either use it
or it won't really help.

1631.62.text:
So I don't really
feel like recipes

1634.05.text:
are meant to be-- I feel like
recipes are meant to be shared.

1640.60.text:
A lot of that
comes from the fact

1641.97.text:
that we obviously use the same
recipe at the bakery for all

1646.25.text:
Every baker has access
to the big recipe book.

1649.81.text:
And it's crazy
the variation that

1651.90.text:
comes, even though
everything is weighed

1654.44.text:
to the gram and everything is
timed almost to the second.

1658.90.text:
And yet, we will still
have huge variations.

1661.47.text:
Because to me, baking
isn't just about-- I mean,

1664.41.text:
everyone talks about
how baking is chemistry

1667.14.text:
And it is, but it's also
so much about who you are

1670.85.text:
and what you put into it, and
how you're feeling that day.

1673.27.text:
I know this sounds
very touchy-feely,

1674.91.text:
but I really feel like
pastry is something

1677.99.text:
that you can tell if
somebody's doing it right

1681.66.text:
And so giving somebody the
recipe isn't the secret.

1685.88.text:
It's all the
thought and the care

1687.90.text:
and the attention that goes into
making it that's the secret.

1690.48.text:
So I'm happy to
share all the recipes

1692.32.text:
and hope that everybody has
that same thought and care.

1698.21.text:
FEMALE SPEAKER: I think we're
out of audience questions.

1700.22.text:
I love that last
thing that you said,

1701.86.text:
because I've always said
that my art is baking

1705.78.text:
and that I put love into
everything that I make.

1708.39.text:
And so I do that
for gifts for people

1710.04.text:
for holidays and everything,
so it was awesome

1713.36.text: Thank you so much for coming.
